leanCodeSectionsTree.body:
User notes:
About this chapter: Chapter 19 provides minimum accepted practices for the design and construction of buildings and structural components using concrete—both plain and reinforced. Chapter 19 relies primarily on the reference to American Concrete Institute (ACI) 318, Building Code Requirements for Structural Concrete. Structural concrete must be designed and constructed to comply with this code and all listed standards. There are also specific provisions addressing slabs-on-ground and shotcrete.
This chapter was extensively reorganized for the 2024 edition. For complete information, see the relocations table in the Preface information of this code.
Code development reminder: Code change proposals to this chapter will be considered by the IBC—Structural Code Development Committee during the 2025 (Group B) Code Development Cycle.

diagrams.title: Subgrade Floor Waterproofing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: When a floor is required to be waterproof by section 1805.3 it is required to be constructed of concrete and structurally able to resist any hydrostatic pressure that ground water may apply to the floor slab. The waterproofing must consist of a membrane and be located below the floor slab. The membrane may be of rubberized asphalt, butyl rubber, fully adhered/fully bonded HDPE or polyolefin composite membrane or not less than 6-mil polyvinyl chloride (PVC) or other approved materials. Joints in the membrane are required to be lapped and sealed in accordance with the membrane manufacturer's installation instructions except for PVC membranes which require a 6" minimum lap.

diagrams.title: PT: Stressing End Anchor Showing Added #4 Bars at Distributed Tendons
Electrical Vaults: Floors
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Where an electrical vault floor is constructed directly over earth the floor is required to be a concrete slab with a minimum thickness of 4". Where the electrical vault has space below it, habitable or not, the floor assembly is required to have minimum fire resistance of 3 hours and adequate structural strength to support the loads that will be imposed upon it.

diagrams.title: Dead End Anchorage at Distributed Tendons
Example - Closure Strip
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Closure strips are temporary gaps that allow sections of slabs on either side to move freely while it shrinks and to reduce stresses caused from the slab being restrained from shrinkage. After a predetermined time, the strip is poured with low / non-shrink concrete or grout. Longer slabs may require multiple pour strips, whereas shorter ones, generally 250 feet measured perpendicular to the strip, or less, may not need any closure strip.

diagrams.title: Construction Joint with no Intermediate Stressing
Example: 16" Square Column to 24" Square Column
Example: Concrete Wall / Beam Intersection Reinforcing
Example: Stressing End Anchor for Distributed Tendons
Example: Construction Joint with Intermediate P.T. Stressing
Example: Profile for Reversed Parabola Tendons
Exterior Envelope: Walls - Mass Walls Above & Below Grade
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The energy code defines the required building envelope thermal performance requirements. When using the R-Value-Based method for thermal performance the opaque assemblies must contain insulation that complies with the requirements of table C402.1.3. The opaque assemblies are essentially the building's roofs, walls, floors that are part of the buildings thermal envelop. The table provides the various minimum R-values for different opaque assemblies based on the building's use (Residential or Other) and climate zone. It is important to note that the table calls out different values for the various types of insulation required in each particular assembly type and assigns a separate R-value for each type of insulation. In some assemblies more than one type of insulation may be required and each type must meet the requirements of the table. For example if the design is calling for both Continuous Insulation and Cavity Insulation at a wall the R-value of each needs comply w/ the table. Where Continuous insulation is required for a wall, the continuous insulation may be installed on the interior or exterior side the wall.

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Stairs at Elevated Slab
Example: Construction Slip Joint at Concrete Shear Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If concrete slabs are restrained from shrinkage, unwanted cracking can occur. In this example, slip material is provided to allow shrinkage of the concrete slab relative to the wall below, before the wall above is poured. Reinforcement from the wall to the slab provides shear transfer. Other configurations are possible.

children.body: The provisions of this chapter shall govern the materials, quality control, design and construction of concrete used in structures.
Structural concrete shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the requirements of this chapter and ACI 318 as supplemented in Section 1905 of this code.

diagrams.title: Example: Int. Column on Footing w/o Pier
Typical Raised Slab over Foam
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Sometimes foam can be used to fill a large void, when an area covered with concrete wants to be installed, but without a large amount of heavy and costly concrete. Normally the use of foam would require a thermal barrier, but covering with at least 1" of concrete or masonry allows the foam to be used without additional protection.

If large areas are covered with concrete, the design professional should ensure that proper support is provided within the structure so that the topping slab is able to be supported. The foam itself may not be a suitable support for large expanses of concrete proper design considerations. Otherwise, the concrete may be susceptible to unwanted cracks and water infiltraton, especially if exposed to the weather.

diagrams.title: Min. Conc. Cover: Steel Core in Cased Pier
Min. Conc. Cover: Cast-in-place, Rock Socket
Construction Joint with no Intermediate Stressing
Example: Concrete Stairs at Elevated Slab
Min. Conc. Cover: Deep Precast Found. Elements
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The concrete cover provided for prestressed and nonprestressed reinforcement in foundations shall be not less than the largest applicable value specified in Table 1808.8.2. Longitudinal bars spaced less than 1-1/2 inches clear distance apart shall be considered to be bundled bars for which the concrete cover provided shall be not less than that required by Section 20.6.1.3.4 of ACI 318. Concrete cover shall be measured from the concrete surface to the outermost surface of the steel to which the cover requirement applies. Where concrete is placed in a temporary or permanent casing or a mandrel, the inside face of the casing or mandrel shall be considered to be the concrete surface.

diagrams.title: Min. Conc. Cover: Cased Deep Foundations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The concrete cover provided for prestressed and non-prestressed reinforcement in foundations shall be not less than the largest applicable value specified in Table 1808.8.2. Longitudinal bars spaced less than 1-1/2 inches clear distance apart shall be considered to be bundled bars for which the concrete cover provided shall be not less than that required by Section 20.6.1.3.4 of ACI 318. Concrete cover shall be measured from the concrete surface to the outermost surface of the steel to which the cover requirement applies. Where concrete is placed in a temporary or permanent casing or a mandrel, the inside face of the casing or mandrel shall be considered to be the concrete surface.

diagrams.title: Min. Conc. Cover: Shallow Foundations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The concrete cover provided for prestressed and non-prestressed reinforcement in foundations shall be not less than the largest applicable value specified in Table 1808.8.2. Longitudinal bars spaced less than 1-1/2 inches clear distance apart shall be considered to be bundled bars for which the concrete cover provided shall be not less than that required by Section 20.6.1.3.4 of ACI 318. Concrete cover shall be measured from the concrete surface to the outermost surface of the steel to which the cover requirement applies. Where concrete is placed in a temporary or permanent casing or a mandrel, the inside face of the casing or mandrel shall be considered to be the concrete surface.

diagrams.title: Min. Conc. Cover: Cast In Place Deep Foundations
diagrams.descriptionHtml: The concrete cover provided for prestressed and nonprestressed reinforcement in foundations shall be not less than the largest applicable value specified in Table 1808.8.2. Longitudinal bars spaced less than 1-1/2 inches clear distance apart shall be considered to be bundled bars for which the concrete cover provided shall be not less than that required by Section 20.6.1.3.4 of ACI 318. Concrete cover shall be measured from the concrete surface to the outermost surface of the steel to which the cover requirement applies. Where concrete is placed in a temporary or permanent casing or a mandrel, the inside face of the casing or mandrel shall be considered to be the concrete surface.

diagrams.title: Beam Pocket
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Beam pockets might be used to allow the top of a concrete retaining or other wall to align with the top of a beam. If beam pockets interrupt a chord of concrete shear wall, special consideration should be made to ensure continuity of the chord around the pocket. In addition, if the wall the beam is set in is also a fire-resistive assembly, then the minimum concrete thickness on the back side of the beam should comply with Chapter 7 of the building code and attention to the protection of the end of the beam may be required as well.

diagrams.title: Example: Construction Joint with Intermediate P.T. Stressing
Example: Interior Steel Column to Foundation

children.body: Cast-in-place structural concrete internally reinforced with glass fiber reinforced polymer (GFRP) reinforcement conforming to ASTM D7957 and designed in accordance with ACI CODE 440.11 shall be permitted where fire-resistance ratings are not required and only for structures assigned to Seismic Design Category A.

Anchoring to concrete shall be in accordance with ACI 318 as supplemented in Section 1905, and applies to cast-in (headed bolts, headed studs and hooked J- or L-bolts), post-installed expansion (torque-controlled and displacement-controlled), undercut, screw, and adhesive anchors.

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Equipment Pad
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Concrete equipment pads, also known as housekeeping pads, allow a piece of equipment to be mounted above the level of the primary slab floor it's located on. The anchorage of the pad to the slab or foundation below should be sufficient to transfer any shear or overturning forces that would be present due to seismic or operational forces. Source: NYC School Construction Authority

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Equipment Curb
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Concrete curbs can be used as a curb to install mechanical or others systems on concrete floors and roofs. Rebar tying the curb into the slab should be designed to account for any overturning forces that may be present from wind or seismic forces on the equipment. Source: New York City School Construction Authority Design Standard

diagrams.title: Example: Steel Column to Conc. Pedestal / Footing
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Sometimes, a round or rectangular pier can be used to transfer loads from a grade beam down to a proper isolated footing at a lower elevation to take advantage of stronger soils or because of weak surface layers. Also, urban or existing building situations may not allow a full pier and grade beam system. Coordination with the soils engineer is critical to determine the best foundation system for the project. Detailing and reinforcement of piers and footings will be different for individual projects, and should be designed by the Structural Engineer of Record.

diagrams.title: Suspended Ceiling Bracing Wires
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Anchorage of bracing wires may require expansion anchors instead of shot pins in high-seismic areas. The diagram shown is one possible example of suspended ceiling bracing wire anchorage to concrete.

Source: OSHPD OPD No. CL4.10

diagrams.title: Example: Interior Metal Stud Partition / Concrete Slab Firestopping
Example: Liquid-Applied Roofing at Rooftop Unit Curb Support
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Liquid-applied roofing is a specific type of roofing system where a liquid membrane is applied to the roof surface, forming a seamless, waterproof layer. The installation of liquid-applied roofing must follow the provisions set forth in Section 1507.14 of the Building Code. Liquid-applied roofing materials must comply with established ASTM standards such as ASTM C836, ASTM C957, or ASTM D3468, ensuring that the materials meet the necessary quality and durability criteria.

children.body: Systems of structural steel acting compositely with reinforced concrete shall be designed in accordance with Section 2202 of this code.
children.displayTitle: 1901.4 Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Structures
children.titleText: Composite Structural Steel and Concrete Structures

children.body:
The construction documents for structural concrete construction shall include:
  1. The specified compressive strength of concrete at the stated ages or stages of construction for which each concrete element is designed.
  2. The specified strength or grade of reinforcement.
  3. The size and location of structural elements, reinforcement and anchors.
  4. Provision for dimensional changes resulting from creep, shrinkage and temperature.
  5. The magnitude and location of prestressing forces.
  6. Anchorage length of reinforcement and location and length of lap splices.
  7. Type and location of mechanical and welded splices of reinforcement.
  8. Details and location of contraction or isolation joints specified for plain concrete.
  9. Minimum concrete compressive strength at time of posttensioning.
  10. Stressing sequence for posttensioning tendons.
  11. For structures assigned to Seismic Design Category D, E or F, a statement if slab on grade is designed as a structural diaphragm.

diagrams.title: Example - Closure Strip
diagrams.descriptionHtml: Closure strips are temporary gaps that allow sections of slabs on either side to move freely while it shrinks and to reduce stresses caused from the slab being restrained from shrinkage. After a predetermined time, the strip is poured with low / non-shrink concrete or grout. Longer slabs may require multiple pour strips, whereas shorter ones, generally 250 feet measured perpendicular to the strip, or less, may not need any closure strip.

children.body: Special inspections and tests of concrete elements of buildings and structures and concreting operations shall be as required by Chapter 17.
Where not indicated in construction documents, structural tolerances for concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with this section.

Structural tolerances for cast-in-place concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with ACI 117.
Exceptions:
  1. Group R-3 detached one- or two-family dwellings are not required to comply with this section.
  2. Shotcrete is not required to comply with this section.

Structural tolerances for precast concrete structural elements shall be in accordance with ACI ITG-7.
Exception: Group R-3 detached one- or two-family dwellings are not required to comply with this section.
Coordination of terminology used in ACI 318 and ASCE 7 shall be in accordance with Section 1902.1.1.

Design displacement  shall be the Design Earthquake Displacement, δDE, defined in ASCE 7 Section 12.8.6.3. For diaphragms that can be idealized as rigid in accordance with ASCE 7 Section 12.3.1.2, δdi, displacement due to diaphragm deformation corresponding to the design earthquake, is permitted to be taken as zero.

children.displayTitle: Section 1903 Specifications for Tests and Materials

children.body: Materials used to produce concrete, concrete itself and testing thereof shall comply with the applicable standards listed in ACI 318.
Glass fiber-reinforced concrete (GFRC) and the materials used in such concrete shall be in accordance with the PCI 128.
Insulating concrete form material used for forming flat concrete walls shall conform to ASTM E2634.
children.displayTitle: 1903.3 Flat Wall Insulating Concrete Form (ICF) Systems
children.titleText: Flat Wall Insulating Concrete Form (ICF) Systems

diagrams.title: Min. Specified Concrete Strength for Foundations
diagrams.descriptionHtml:
Per ACI 318-14, Section 19.2.1.1, the value of f'c shall be specified in construction documents and shall be in accordance with (a) through (c):
(a) Limits in Table 19.2.1.1
(b) Durability requirements in Table 19.3.2.1
(c) Structural strength requirements

children.body:
Structural concrete shall conform to the durability requirements of ACI 318.
Exception: For Group R-2 and R-3 occupancies not more than three stories above grade plane, the specified compressive strength, f´c, for concrete in basement walls, foundation walls, exterior walls and other vertical surfaces exposed to the weather shall be not less than 3,000 psi (20.7 MPa).

diagrams.title: Example: Construction Slip Joint at Concrete Shear Wall
diagrams.descriptionHtml: If concrete slabs are restrained from shrinkage, unwanted cracking can occur. In this example, slip material is provided to allow shrinkage of the concrete slab relative to the wall below, before the wall above is poured. Reinforcement from the wall to the slab provides shear transfer. Other configurations are possible.

children.body: The registered design professional shall assign nonstructural concrete a freeze-thaw exposure class, as defined in ACI 318, based on the anticipated exposure of nonstructural concrete. Nonstructural concrete shall have a minimum specified compressive strength, f´c, of 2,500 psi (17.2 MPa) for Class F0; 3,000 psi (20.7 MPa) for Class F1; and 3,500 psi (24.1 MPa) for Classes F2 and F3. Nonstructural concrete shall be air entrained in accordance with ACI 318.

diagrams.title: Example: Concrete Steps with Nosing Plates
diagrams.descriptionHtml: This example shows items that may be to the designer's prerogative, such as use of epoxy coated bars, embedded nosing plates, etc. Some jurisdictions, such as California, require exterior stairs to have contrasting striping for the visually impaired. Check with local requirements for specific detailed requirements for your area. Source: NYCSCA Standard Details

children.body: In addition to the provisions of ACI 318, structural concrete shall comply with the requirements of Section 1905.

Modify existing definitions and add the following definitions to ACI 318 Section 2.3:
  • CAST-IN-PLACE CONCRETE EQUIVALENT DIAPHRAGM. A cast-in-place noncomposite topping slab diaphragm, as defined in Section 18.12.5, or a diaphragm constructed with precast concrete components that uses closure strips between precast components with detailing that meets the requirements of ACI 318 for the Seismic Design Category of the structure.
  • DETAILED PLAIN CONCRETE STRUCTURAL WALL. A wall complying with the requirements of Chapter 14, and Section 1905.5 of the International Building Code.
  • ORDINARY PLAIN CONCRETE STRUCTURAL WALL. A wall complying with the requirements of Chapter 14, excluding 14.6.2.
  • ORDINARY PRECAST STRUCTURAL WALL. A precast wall complying with the requirements of Chapters 1 through 13, 15, 16 and 19 through 26.
  • ORDINARY REINFORCED CONCRETE STRUCTURAL WALL. A cast-in-place wall complying with the requirements of Chapters 1 through 13, 15, 16 and 19 through 26.
  • PRECAST CONCRETE DIAPHRAGM. A diaphragm constructed with precast concrete components, with or without a cast-in-place topping, that includes the use of discrete connectors or joint reinforcement to transmit diaphragm forces.
Intermediate precast structural walls shall comply with Section 18.5 of ACI 318 and this section.

Connections that are designed to yield shall be capable of maintaining 80 percent of their design strength at the deformation induced by the design displacement or shall use Type 2 mechanical splices.

Foundations resisting earthquake-induced forces or transferring earthquake-induced forces between a structure and the ground shall comply with the requirements of Section 18.13 of ACI 318 and other applicable provisions of ACI 318 unless modified by Chapter 18.
children.displayTitle: 1905.4 Foundations Designed to Resist Earthquake Forces
children.titleText: Foundations Designed to Resist Earthquake Forces

children.body: Detailed plain concrete structural walls are walls conforming to the requirements of ordinary plain concrete structural walls and Section 1905.5.1.

Reinforcement shall be provided as follows:
  1. Vertical reinforcement of not less than 0.20 square inch (129 mm2) in cross-sectional area shall be provided continuously from support to support at each corner, at each side of each opening, and at the ends of walls. The continuous vertical bar required beside an opening is permitted to substitute for one of the two No. 5 bars required by Section 14.6.1 of ACI 318.
  2. Horizontal reinforcement of not less than0.20 square inch (129 mm2) in cross-sectional area shall be provided:
    1. Continuously at structurally connected roof and floor levels and at the top of walls.
    2. At the bottom of load-bearing walls or in the top of foundations where doweled to the wall.
    3. At a maximum spacing of 120 inches (3048 mm).
Reinforcement at the top and bottom of openings, where used in determining the maximum spacing specified in Item 2.3, shall be continuous in the wall.
Structural plain concrete elements shall comply with this section in lieu of Section 14.1.4 of ACI 318.

In structures assigned to Seismic Design Category A or B, detached one- and two-family dwellings three stories or less in height constructed with stud-bearing walls are permitted to have plain concrete footings without longitudinal reinforcement.
children.displayTitle: 1905.6.1 Seismic Design Categories A and B
children.titleText: Seismic Design Categories A and B

children.body:
Structures assigned to Seismic Design Category C, D, E or F shall not have elements of structural plain concrete, except as follows:
  1. Structural plain concrete basement, foundation or other walls below the base as defined in ASCE/SEI 7 are permitted in detached one- and two-family dwellings three stories or less in height constructed with stud-bearing walls. In dwellings assigned to Seismic Design Category D or E, the height of the wall shall not exceed 8 feet (2438 mm), the thickness shall be not less than 71/2 inches (190 mm), and the wall shall retain not more than 4 feet (1219 mm) of unbalanced fill. Walls shall have reinforcement in accordance with Section 14.6.1 of ACI 318.
  2. Isolated footings of plain concrete supporting pedestals or columns are permitted, provided that the projection of the footing beyond the face of the supported member does not exceed the footing thickness.
    Exception: In detached one- and two-family dwellings three stories or less in height, the projection of the footing beyond the face of the supported member is permitted to exceed the footing thickness.
  3. Plain concrete footings supporting walls are permitted, provided that the footings have not fewer than two continuous longitudinal reinforcing bars. Bars shall not be smaller than No. 4 and shall have a total area of not less than 0.002 times the gross cross-sectional area of the footing. For footings that exceed 8 inches (203 mm) in thickness, not fewer than one bar shall be provided at the top and bottom of the footing. Continuity of reinforcement shall be provided at corners and intersections.
    Exceptions:
    1. Where assigned to Seismic Design Category C, detached one- and two-family dwellings three stories or less in height constructed with stud-bearing walls are permitted to have plain concrete footings without longitudinal reinforcement.
    2. For foundation systems consisting of a plain concrete footing and a plain concrete stemwall, not fewer than one bar shall be provided at the top of the stemwall and at the bottom of the footing.
    3. Footings cast monolithically with a slab-on-ground shall have not fewer than one No. 4 bar at the top and bottom of the footing or one No. 5 bar or two No. 4 bars in the middle third of the footing depth.
children.displayTitle: 1905.6.2 Seismic Design Categories C, D, E and F
children.titleText: Seismic Design Categories C, D, E and F

children.body: For the design requirements for anchors, Sections 1905.7.1 and 1905.7.2 provide exceptions that are permitted to ACI 318.

The following exception is permitted to ACI 318 Section 17.10.5.2:
Exception: Anchors designed to resist wall out-of-plane forces with design strengths equal to or greater than the force determined in accordance with ASCE/SEI 7 Equation 12.11-1 or 12.14-10 shall be deemed to satisfy Section 17.10.5.3(d) of ACI 318.

The following exceptions are permitted to ACI 318 Section 17.10.6.2:
Exceptions:
  1. For the calculation of the in-plane shear strength of anchor bolts attaching wood sill plates of bearing or nonbearing walls of light-frame wood structures to foundations or foundation stemwalls, the in-plane shear strength in accordance with Sections 17.7.2 and 17.7.3 of ACI 318 need not be computed and Section 17.10.6.3 of ACI 318 shall be deemed to be satisfied provided that all of the following are met:
    1. The allowable in-plane shear strength of the anchor is determined in accordance with ANSI/AWC NDS Table 12E for lateral design values parallel to grain.
    2. The maximum anchor nominal diameter is 5/8 inch (16 mm).
    3. Anchor bolts are embedded into concrete not less than 7 inches (178 mm).
    4. Anchor bolts are located not less than 13/4 inches (45 mm) from the edge of the concrete parallel to the length of the wood sill plate.
    5. Anchor bolts are located not less than 15 anchor diameters from the edge of the concrete perpendicular to the length of the wood sill plate.
    6. The sill plate is 2-inch (51 mm) or 3-inch (76 mm) nominal thickness.
  2. For the calculation of the in-plane shear strength of anchor bolts attaching cold-formed steel track of bearing or nonbearing walls of light-frame construction to foundations or foundation stemwalls, the in-plane shear strength in accordance with Sections 17.7.2 and 17.7.3 of ACI 318 need not be computed and 17.10.6.3 shall be deemed to be satisfied provided that all of the following are met:
    Allowable in-plane shear strength of exempt anchors, parallel to the edge of concrete, shall be permitted to be determined in accordance with AISI S100 Section J3.3.1.
    1. The maximum anchor nominal diameter is 5/8 inch (16 mm).
    2. Anchors are embedded into concrete a minimum of 7 inches (178 mm).
    3. Anchors are located a minimum of 13/4 inches (45 mm) from the edge of the concrete parallel to the length of the track.
    4. Anchors are located a minimum of 15 anchor diameters from the edge of the concrete perpendicular to the length of the track.
    5. The track is 33 to 68 mil (0.84 mm to 1.73 mm) designation thickness.
  3. In light-frame construction bearing or nonbearing walls, shear strength of concrete anchors less than or equal to 1 inch (25 mm) in diameter attaching sill plate or track to foundation or foundation stemwalls need not satisfy Sections 17.10.6.3(a) through (c) when the design strength of the anchors is determined in accordance with Section 17.7.2.1(c) of ACI 318.

For Group R-3 occupancies and buildings of other occupancies less than two stories above grade plane of light-frame construction, the required thickness of plain concrete footings is permitted to be 6 inches (152 mm), provided that the footing does not extend more than 4 inches (102 mm) on either side of the supported wall.

Structural concrete slabs-on-ground shall comply with all applicable provisions of this chapter. Slabs-on-ground shall be considered structural concrete where required by ACI 318 or where designed to transmit either of the following:
  1. Vertical loads or lateral forces from other parts of the structure to the soil.
  2. Vertical loads or lateral forces from other parts of the structure to foundations.

Nonstructural slabs-on-ground shall be required to comply with Sections 1904.2, 1907.3 and 1907.4. Portions of the nonstructural slabs-on-ground used to resist uplift forces or overturning shall be designed in accordance with accepted engineering practice throughout the entire portion designated as dead load to resist uplift forces or overturning.
The thickness of concrete floor slabs supported directly on the ground shall be not less than 31/2 inches (89 mm).

A 6-mil (0.006 inch; 0.15 mm) polyethylene vapor retarder with joints lapped not less than 6 inches (152 mm) shall be placed between the base course or subgrade and the concrete floor slab, or other approved equivalent methods or materials shall be used to retard vapor transmission through the floor slab.
Exception: A vapor retarder is not required:
  1. For detached structures accessory to occupancies in Group R-3, such as garages, utility buildings or other unheated facilities.
  2. For unheated storage rooms having an area of less than 70 square feet (6.5 m2) and carports attached to occupancies in Group R-3.
  3. For buildings of other occupancies where migration of moisture through the slab from below will not be detrimental to the intended occupancy of the building.
  4. For driveways, walks, patios and other flatwork that will not be enclosed at a later date.
  5. Where approved based on local site conditions.
Shotcrete shall be in accordance with the requirements of ACI 318.
